questions.question: When Sternberg asked members of the public to generate and then rate behaviours characteristic of intelligence, which factor triad captured the resulting structure?
options: reasoning, associative memory, perceptual speed
interpersonal intelligence, intrapersonal intelligence, intellectual self-assertion
practical problem solving, verbal ability, social competence
fluid intelligence, crystallised intelligence, processing speed
questions.answer: practical problem solving, verbal ability, social competence

questions.question: In Duncan and Fiske's catalogue of turn-yielding cues, which element was NOT included?
options: a deliberate increase in speech rate at the end of a clause
a rise and fall in pitch at the end of a clause
a drop in loudness near turn completion
termination of hand gestures at the end of the turn
questions.answer: a deliberate increase in speech rate at the end of a clause

questions.question: In the harsh vs soft bases of power distinction described, which feature is most characteristic of soft bases?
options: Depend primarily on economic and physical outcomes that are tangible and explicit
Tend to produce influence that is self-sustaining and relies on more subjective social outcomes
Require surveillance to maintain compliance
both A and C
questions.answer: Tend to produce influence that is self-sustaining and relies on more subjective social outcomes

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT listed as a criticism of projective personality tests in the lecture notes?
options: Weak predictive power for behaviour
High susceptibility to acquiescence responding due to transparent items
Lack of convergence with psychometrically sound tests
Low reliability because different scorers often disagree
questions.answer: High susceptibility to acquiescence responding due to transparent items

questions.question: Which claim best matches Thurstone's reinterpretation of Spearman's g (as described in the notes)?
options: g is best understood as two components—fluid and crystallised intelligence—that together explain test performance
g is a causal factor that produces performance on each primary mental ability
g is an emergent outcome of several primary mental abilities rather than their cause
both A and B
questions.answer: g is an emergent outcome of several primary mental abilities rather than their cause

questions.question: Within the approach/inhibition theory of power, which constellation best characterises the low-power state?
options: Attention to rewards, positive emotions, automatic cognition, disinhibition
Attention to threats, positive emotions, automatic cognition, disinhibition
Attention to threats, negative emotions (eg embarrassment/fear/guilt), systematic cognition, situationally constrained behaviour
Attention to rewards, negative emotions, systematic cognition, situationally constrained behaviour
questions.answer: Attention to threats, negative emotions (eg embarrassment/fear/guilt), systematic cognition, situationally constrained behaviour

questions.question: A politician responds to a hostile question by giving a clear and direct statement, but frames it as what 'people think' rather than giving any personal stance. In equivocation theory, which dimension is primarily being manipulated?
options: Sender dimension
Content dimension
Receiver dimension
Context dimension
questions.answer: Sender dimension

questions.question: In the section discussing factorial invariance as a challenge to interpreting the Flynn effect, what was the reported outcome of Wicherts et al's multi-method assessment?
options: Score gains were evident across each of the different methods used to evaluate change
Gains were confined to a single factor, suggesting a purely methodological artefact
No gains were observed when cohorts were compared against original test norms
both B and C
questions.answer: Score gains were evident across each of the different methods used to evaluate change

questions.question: A personality inventory shows the same factor structure and comparable internal reliability across two cultures, yet a given raw score appears to reflect different trait intensity in each culture, necessitating separate norms. Which equivalence issue is this?
options: Linguistic equivalence
Construct equivalence
Psychological/cultural equivalence
Psychometric (scalar) equivalence
questions.answer: Psychometric (scalar) equivalence

questions.question: In Milgram's variations (as summarised), which procedural change was described as increasing obedience relative to the standard setup?
options: making the teacher and learner friends
removing the experimenter's physical presence
having the participant read the words while another person administered the shocks
having confederates pressure the participant to disobey
questions.answer: having the participant read the words while another person administered the shocks

questions.question: Which claim(s) align with the empirical pattern reported for applause invitations in UK party conference speeches analysed by Heritage and Greatbatch?
options: Contrasts were linked to roughly a third of collective applause
Three-part lists accounted for just over a tenth of collective applause
Across devices identified by Heritage and Greatbatch, more than two thirds of collective applause was associated with these rhetorical formats
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the deviation IQ formula IQ = 100 + 15((score − population mean)/population SD), what does the factor 15 achieve?
options: It rescales the standardised score so that the IQ standard deviation is 15 points
It centres the distribution so that the mean is always 15
It converts mental age into chronological age
It corrects scores for the Flynn effect
questions.answer: It rescales the standardised score so that the IQ standard deviation is 15 points

questions.question: In Bandura's description of internal self-regulatory processes, which function most directly refers to evaluating one's own performance while pursuing goals?
options: Self-monitoring (evaluating performance)
Self-diagnostic (identifying patterns across situations)
Self-motivation (setting step-like goals)
Proxy agency (relying on others to act)
questions.answer: Self-monitoring (evaluating performance)

questions.question: Which statement most closely matches an item used to measure Social Dominance Orientation (as described in the notes)?
options: If certain groups stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems
I tend to overestimate how widely my personal preferences are shared by others
I prefer leaders who are admired for their achievements rather than feared
People should resist norms mainly when their behaviour is descriptively deviant
questions.answer: If certain groups stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems

questions.question: Within the neuro-cultural model of emotional expression, which pairing is correctly matched?
options: Amplification — exaggerating an emotional expression
Attenuation — weakening an emotional expression
Substitution — replacing one emotional display with another
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: Which statement best captures the relationship between Carroll's model and the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) framework described?
options: CHC replaces g with independent intelligences that do not interact
CHC treats crystallised knowledge as a narrow (stratum 1) ability unrelated to broad domains
CHC combines Carroll's hierarchical strata with Cattell's fluid/crystallised distinction to organise broad and narrow abilities
CHC is designed specifically as a language-free test like Raven's matrices
questions.answer: CHC combines Carroll's hierarchical strata with Cattell's fluid/crystallised distinction to organise broad and narrow abilities

questions.question: According to the two-factor model of trait impressions from faces described, the two dimensions are best characterised as judgements about:
options: whether the target intends harm/help and whether the target can enact that intent
how extroverted and conscientious the target is
whether the target belongs to the observer's ingroup and whether the target is high status
how truthful the target is and how intelligent they are
questions.answer: whether the target intends harm/help and whether the target can enact that intent

questions.question: After a product was anthropomorphised and then shown to fail, whose attitudes were described as most likely to become more negative compared with the non-anthropomorphised framing?
options: Incremental theorists
Entity theorists
Neither; anthropomorphism buffered the brand equally regardless of mindset
both A and B
questions.answer: Entity theorists

questions.question: In Bull's analysis of political interview questions (as summarised), which pattern best characterises how conflictual questions related to politicians' responses?
options: Conflictual questions were rare and usually elicited direct replies
Conflictual questions were common enough to matter and were more likely to elicit equivocation than direct replies
Non-conflictual questions were less common and mostly elicited equivocation
Equivocation occurred equally often for conflictual and non-conflictual questions
questions.answer: Conflictual questions were common enough to matter and were more likely to elicit equivocation than direct replies

questions.question: When intelligence was examined using genome-wide data in unrelated adults (as described), what proportion of variation in intelligence was associated with common SNPs?
options: about 10–20%
about 20–30%
about 40–50%
about 69–74%
questions.answer: about 40–50%

questions.question: In Eysenck's hierarchy (super-trait → trait → habitual response → specific response), which level corresponds to recurring behavioural patterns that sit between broad traits and single acts?
options: Specific responses
Habitual responses
Cardinal traits
Primary mental abilities
questions.answer: Habitual responses

questions.question: In the indirect reciprocity game described, which statement(s) reflect the observed role of public image score?
options: Donors tended to give more when the receiver's image score was higher than average
Participants with low image scores were more likely to donate and improve their image
By the end of the game, image score was strongly correlated with earnings
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: Bull and Wells argued that delivery cues function as a gate for whether rhetorical devices are treated as applause invitations. Which pattern did they report?
options: Rhetorical devices produced synchronous applause regardless of delivery
Applause was synchronous mainly when rhetorical devices were absent
Delivery affected how loud applause was, but not when it began
When delivery signalled an invitation, applause was almost always synchronous; when it did not, applause was almost always asynchronous
questions.answer: When delivery signalled an invitation, applause was almost always synchronous; when it did not, applause was almost always asynchronous

questions.question: In the Multiple Intelligences account described, which claim best captures Gardner's reason for resisting a single-unitary intelligence score?
options: Intelligence reflects distinct processing systems that can operate irrespective of particular sensory inputs
Intelligence is best measured via reaction times and sensory acuity
Intelligence is a single g factor captured by combining all test scores into one number
Intelligence is fixed within Western cultures and cannot change
questions.answer: Intelligence reflects distinct processing systems that can operate irrespective of particular sensory inputs

questions.question: A student privately wants more intergroup friendships but avoids approaching an outgroup table because they assume (incorrectly) the others would reject them. This pattern is best labelled:
options: False consensus effect
Pluralistic ignorance
Normative influence
all of the above
questions.answer: Pluralistic ignorance

questions.question: In Chabrol et al's cluster solution for the Dark Tetrad (as summarised), which profile was associated with being less depressed?
options: Low on all four traits
High on Machiavellianism and sadism
High on narcissism and psychopathy
High on all four traits
questions.answer: High on narcissism and psychopathy

questions.question: What pattern did Lynn and Irwing's meta-analysis (as described) report for sex differences in general intelligence across development?
options: A female advantage emerges after adolescence with reduced variance among males
A male advantage is present in children and remains constant with age
No differences in children, but a small male advantage and greater male score dispersion appear with age
Large female advantage across all ages and cultures
questions.answer: No differences in children, but a small male advantage and greater male score dispersion appear with age

questions.question: In the Welsh accent study described, when challenged by an English-accented speaker, what did integrative learners tend to do?
options: They converged by softening their accent when challenged
They diverged by broadening their accent and sometimes introducing Welsh words/phrases
They shifted to a standard accent to increase perceived status
They showed no systematic accommodation changes
questions.answer: They diverged by broadening their accent and sometimes introducing Welsh words/phrases

questions.question: In the meta-analytic pattern of Health Locus of Control correlates summarised, which statement(s) were reported?
options: Internal HLoC was linked to healthier behaviours such as exercise and healthy diet
Chance HLoC was linked to poorer behaviours such as smoking
Powerful-others HLoC was linked to higher depression/anxiety despite some links to physical quality of life
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: Which pairing correctly matches positive vs negative eugenics as defined in the intelligence lecture notes?
options: Positive eugenics discourages reproduction among the 'fit'; negative eugenics encourages reproduction among the 'unfit'
Positive eugenics refers to forced sterilisation; negative eugenics refers to IQ testing in schools
Positive eugenics refers to immigration quotas; negative eugenics refers to bilingual education policies
Positive eugenics encourages reproduction among those perceived to have superior traits; negative eugenics discourages/restricts reproduction among those perceived to have poor hereditary traits
questions.answer: Positive eugenics encourages reproduction among those perceived to have superior traits; negative eugenics discourages/restricts reproduction among those perceived to have poor hereditary traits

questions.question: In the small-group 'Lunar Landing' style task described, which two indicators were used to quantify a person's social influence within the group?
options: movement of group decisions toward a member's initial rankings and third-party eye gaze toward that member
self-reported fear of the target and admiration of the target
number of intrusive interruptions and reply rate
basal cortisol level and cortisol reactivity
questions.answer: movement of group decisions toward a member's initial rankings and third-party eye gaze toward that member

questions.question: In the typology of political interview question forms presented, which category best fits a follow-up such as 'the Everyman cinema?'
options: Yes-no/polar
Declarative
Moodless
Indirect
questions.answer: Moodless

questions.question: Which description best matches the rationale for using an Implicit Association Test-type measure in personality assessment (as outlined)?
options: It infers automatic associations from response-time differences, making deliberate impression management harder
It relies on ambiguous stimuli to elicit unconscious themes
It requires respondents to explicitly endorse trait adjectives on a Likert scale
both B and C
questions.answer: It infers automatic associations from response-time differences, making deliberate impression management harder

questions.question: In the Deary et al follow-up of the Scottish cohort described, the cross-time correlation indicating individual stability of IQ was approximately:
In the section on minority influence, what evidence (beyond overt agreement rates) suggested that a consistent minority could alter perception rather than just public responding?
options: An increase in explicit identification with the minority group
A systematic speeding of colour-naming responses
A shift in the blue–green categorisation boundary toward the minority's label
A decrease in the perceived legitimacy of the majority
questions.answer: A shift in the blue–green categorisation boundary toward the minority's label

questions.question: Which statement best distinguishes micro-expressions from subtle expressions as defined in the nonverbal communication notes?
options: Micro-expressions are fleeting full expressions lasting fractions of a second, whereas subtle expressions are partial fragments of an expression
Micro-expressions are culturally learned display rules, whereas subtle expressions are innate
Micro-expressions refer only to posture, whereas subtle expressions refer only to speech
Micro-expressions occur only when lying, whereas subtle expressions occur only when telling the truth
questions.answer: Micro-expressions are fleeting full expressions lasting fractions of a second, whereas subtle expressions are partial fragments of an expression

questions.question: In Rotter's original framework, behaviour potential is conceptualised as the product of which two components?
options: reinforcement value × expectancy
self-efficacy × trait anxiety
dominance motivation × prestige motivation
need for cognition × need for affect
questions.answer: reinforcement value × expectancy

questions.question: Which consideration(s) were highlighted as complicating simple 'genes + environment' interpretations of intelligence differences?
options: Gene–environment correlation can lead genetically influenced traits to shape the environments people experience
Differential susceptibility implies some genetic profiles make individuals more sensitive to environmental conditions
Assortative mating violates the assumption that mating is random, affecting estimates
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the evidence summarised under system justification theory, which pattern was reported when comparing implicit evaluations across sexual orientation groups?
options: Gay participants showed implicit ingroup favouritism, whereas straight participants showed implicit outgroup favouritism
Both groups showed strong explicit outgroup favouritism
Straight participants showed implicit outgroup favouritism, whereas gay participants showed implicit ingroup favouritism
Gay participants showed implicit outgroup favouritism toward straight people, while straight participants did not show a comparable implicit preference for gay people
questions.answer: Gay participants showed implicit outgroup favouritism toward straight people, while straight participants did not show a comparable implicit preference for gay people

questions.question: In Giles and Smith's study on 'optimal' accommodation, which accommodation profile was associated with the most favourable evaluations?
options: Converging simultaneously on speech rate, content, and pronunciation
Converging on two dimensions (speech rate and content, or pronunciation) rather than all three
Diverging on pronunciation while converging on speech rate
all of the above
questions.answer: Converging on two dimensions (speech rate and content, or pronunciation) rather than all three

questions.question: In the university wellbeing example, which self-efficacy facet referred to sustaining study behaviour despite tempting alternatives?
options: Emotional self-efficacy
Self-regulated learning self-efficacy
Social self-efficacy
Proxy agency
questions.answer: Self-regulated learning self-efficacy

questions.question: An intelligence test produces highly consistent scores across repeated administrations, yet it is unclear whether it captures the intended construct. Which interpretation matches the tutorial's point about reliability and validity?
options: A test can show strong reliability but still lack validity
High test-retest reliability guarantees high construct validity
Validity refers to item inter-correlation, so it is already demonstrated
Reliability refers to universal agreement on a theory of intelligence
questions.answer: A test can show strong reliability but still lack validity

questions.question: In the need-for-affect/need-for-cognition message-matching study described, which pattern was observed?
options: Participants high in need for affect were more persuaded by affect-oriented messages than cognition-oriented messages
Participants high in need for cognition were more persuaded by cognition-oriented messages than affect-oriented messages
The match effect was described as especially pronounced among those high in need for affect
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: In the expanded typology of applause-inviting devices, what term was used for speakers' follow-up actions that actively seek an audience response when applause does not immediately occur?
options: Position taking
Headline-punchline
Pursuit
Three-part list
questions.answer: Pursuit

questions.question: In the HEXACO-60 inventory mentioned, which trait is the additional factor relative to the Big Five framework (as presented in the notes)?
options: Honesty-humility
Emotionality
Neuroticism
Openness
questions.answer: Honesty-humility

questions.question: Which pairing(s) correctly match audience resistance strategies with company tactics aimed at neutralising them (as summarised)?
options: Avoidance ↔ forced exposure / branded content / viral marketing
Contesting ↔ two-sided advertising / distraction / safety cues
Empowering ↔ self-affirmation / freedom
all of the above
questions.answer: all of the above

questions.question: According to the APA task force consensus described, what can be concluded about average IQ differences observed between African American and white American groups?
options: They are definitively genetic and should guide social policy
They do not exist; any reported differences are entirely due to test bias
Average differences may be observed, but there is no definite evidence they are genetic; cultural factors are more likely
They are genetic because IQ scores are stable within individuals
questions.answer: Average differences may be observed, but there is no definite evidence they are genetic; cultural factors are more likely

questions.question: A response is clear and directed at the interviewer, but it answers a different question than the one asked. In equivocation theory, this primarily reflects equivocation on which dimension?
options: Context dimension
Sender dimension
Content dimension
Receiver dimension
questions.answer: Context dimension

questions.question: Bandura describes multiple forms of agency. Which option captures the forms of agency that explicitly involve others (rather than solely the self acting directly)?
options: both B and C
Proxy agency
Collective agency
Personal agency
questions.answer: both B and C

questions.question: In the public goods game example described, what happened to cooperation once costly punishment was introduced partway through the repeated rounds?
options: Contributions typically declined over time but increased sharply once punishment was introduced, even though punishment was costly
Contributions stayed constant across rounds and punishment had little effect
Punishment reduced contributions by increasing hostility and retaliation
Punishment eliminated the need for cooperation, so contributions fell to zero
questions.answer: Contributions typically declined over time but increased sharply once punishment was introduced, even though punishment was costly
